text: The rhizoplane is the region of soil directly contacting the plant root surface.
The rhizosphere is the soil outside the rhizoplane that receives substances from the root, such as mucilage, sloughed cells, and exudates.
Mycorrhizae greatly enhance the plant’s uptake of water, as well as minerals such as nitrogen and phosphorus.
In addition, the hyphae sequester toxins, and they actually distribute organic substances from one plant to another.
may acquire 25% of the photosynthetic product of their hosts in exchange for tremendously expanding access to soil resources.
Ectomycorrhizal hyphae do not penetrate cells.
